title-group.article-title: Numerical and experimental research of bidirectional thrust bearings used in pump-turbines

abstract.p: A three-dimensional thermo-elasto-hydro-dynamic model for bidirectional thrust bearings used in pump-turbines taking into account the temperature-viscosity effect as well as thermal-elastic deformations in the pad and runner surface was set up. The finite difference method was employed to solve the thermo-hydro-dynamic model, and the thermal-elastic deformations in the pad and runner were obtained by the finite element software ANSYS11.0. The data transfer between the thermo-hydro-dynamic model and ANSYS11.0 was carried out automatically by an interface program. Laboratory test was performed on the Harbin Electric Machinery 3000 ton thrust bearing test rig. A detailed comparison between the experimental results and numerical predictions showed quite good overall agreement on the oil film thickness, pressure and temperature, which provided an evidence of validation of the three-dimensional thermo-elasto-hydro-dynamic model coupled with finite difference method and finite element method developed in this article.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pump storage power station is recognized worldwide as a reliable peaking power, as a result of its good performance on the network balancing with other unpredictable or rebellious power generation, such as conventional, wind and nuclear power plants which cannot be easily and quickly adjusted to demand of the power. Bidirectional thrust bearing is a key component of the pump turbine unit in a pump storage power station, whose performance will directly affect the reliability of unit operation.

Large hydro generators have usually vertical axes of rotation in order to minimize deflections due to the weight, assembly inaccuracies and vibrations. Thus the main load in a pump turbine is carried by the bidirectional hydrodynamic thrust bearing. Since conventional thrust bearings in hydro generators are normally designed as unidirectional ones, the best load capacity may be obtained when the circumferential eccentric ratio is 58–60%.1 However, the circumferential eccentric ratio of bidirectional thrust bearings in reversible hydro generators has to be designed 50% central support, in order to get favorable lubrication performance in both directions.

The lubrication performance of unidirectional thrust bearings have been studied in various literatures.2–8 Currently used calculation methods for hydrodynamic lubrication can be divided into following three aspects: hydro-dynamic (HD), thermo-hydro-dynamic (THD) and thermo-elasto-hydro-dynamic (TEHD). As early as in 1940s, Christopherson9 and Cope10 has built up the HD model of thrust bearings, which laid solid foundation for the analysis of lubrication performance of thrust bearings. The concept of THD was first put forward on formal occasions by Dowson and Hudson.11,12 They took into account the oil heating and variable viscosity (as a function of temperature) through the thickness of the lubricant film. Gero et al.13 performed a three-dimensional (3D) THD finite element scheme for fluid film bearings treating the film and pad as a single continuum and solving their temperature fields simultaneously. Tieu14,15 applied finite element method (FEM) to analysis of both infinite-width and finite-width thrust bearings, which can tilt circumferentially. Almqvist et al.16 presented a 3D THD model of hydrodynamic thrust bearings, which can tilt both radially and circumferentially, and allows for 3D temperature distribution in the oil film and in the pad, as well as 2D temperature variation in the runner. The numerical results obtained by finite difference method showed fairly good agreement with the experimental data. Nowadays, more and more scholars believe that the TEHD model can predict the lubrication performance of large thrust bearings more accurately. Sternlicht et al.17 developed an adiabatic TEHD model of centrally pivoted, sector thrust bearings, in which the elastic deformations due to the pressure distribution and thermal gradients were considered. Abdel-Latif,2 Ettles and Anderson,3 Dabrowski and Wasilczuk7 and Glavatskih and Fillon18 have employed 3D TEHD models to analyze the lubrication performance of thrust bearings with Babbitt-faced or PTFE-faced pads.

The objective of this work is to develop a 3D TEHD model and carry out a full-size prototype simulation test for bidirectional thrust bearings. Subsequently, through a detailed comparison between the numerical predictions and experimental investigation, evidence of the fidelity of the 3D TEHD model proposed in this article was obtained.

sec.title: Test rig and instrumentation
sec.p:
The 3000 ton thrust bearing test rig was employed to study the performance characteristics of large thrust bearings. A schematic of the test rig is shown in Figure 1. The rotor was driven by a 2 × 1500 kW DC motor with an adjustable speed controller and loaded through hydrostatic bearings with hydraulic cylinders. The maximum rotating speed and loading capacity are 600 r/min and 29.43 MN, respectively. Figure 1.
Schematic of the test rig.
1-Lifting device; 2-Driving motor; 3-Hydrostatic bearing; 4-Test bearing.

Four piezoresistive pressure sensors, 5 displacement sensors of eddy current type and 15 resistance temperature detectors (five at each layer through radial direction) were installed in the runner as shown in Figure 2. Twelve resistance temperature detectors were placed in the bearing pillow, as well as 32 resistance temperature detectors distributed in two layers (4 × 4 in each layer) were placed in the thrust pad as shown in Figure 3. The pressure sensors were manufactured by KISTLER with a measuring range of 0–20 MPa and an accuracy of 0.3%, the displacement sensors were manufactured by BENTLY with a measuring range of 0–2000 µm, as well as the temperature detectors were manufactured by ALSTOM-CH with an accuracy of ±0.1 °C. Figure 2.
Sensor positions in the runner. Figure 3.
Temperature sensor positions in the pad.

sec.title: Test bearing
sec.p:
The test bearing is an equalizing pivoted sector pad thrust bearing consisting of bearing pillow and thrust pad with 4 mm babbitt-faced layer as shown in Figure 4. The pads are supported by double elastic plates which allow for the adjustment of each of the pads separately with a deviation of load distribution within ±5%. Figure 4.
Test bearing with double elastic plate supporting structure.

The hot oil is pumped out from the bearing housing with the use of self-pumping devices in the runner by means of centrifugal and viscous pump effects, and then cooled by two plate coolers. Additionally, there is an oil distributor that sprays the cold oil on the rotating runner surface in order to introduce cool oil closer to the point of entry into the film wedge. The schematic diagram of oil circulation system is shown in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Schematic diagram of oil circulation system.

The test bearing characteristics and operating conditions are given in Table 1. The material properties and oil characteristics are shown in Table 2. In order to give a possibility of a realistic simulation, the main principle is to ensure the average circumferential velocity and specific pressure of test bearing the same with prototype bearing. As shown in Figure 6, since the width of runner is much larger than that of bearing, the bearing’s geometric center is set 675 mm far away from the coordinate center that is the runner’ center. By this way, the diameter of pivot is amplified from 2042 mm (in practice) to 3392 mm (in test rig). As a consequence, the rotational speed should be reduced from 235 r/min (in practice) to 140 r/min (in test rig) in order to keep the average circumferential velocity consistent with actual condition. sec.title: Three-dimensional TEHD model
sec.p: In this section, a 3D TEHD model and the boundary conditions are presented. A generalized Reynolds equation taking into account thermal effects and a 3D energy equation are applied to the lubricant. The Laplace’s equations are used for heat conduction in the pad and runner, respectively. In addition, the thermal and elastic deformations on the active surface of the pad and runner are considered.

sec.p: Under steady-state operating conditions, for the laminar and Newtonian incompressible fluid with constant density, the generalized Reynolds equation in a cylindrical coordinate can be written as follows (19) (1)∂∂r(rF2∂p∂r)+1r∂∂θ(F2∂p∂θ)=Ωr∂∂θ(F1F0) where F0, F1 and F2 are the integrals defined by F0=∫0 hdzμ,F1=∫0 hzdzμ,F2=∫0 hz(z-F1/F0)μdz
The pressure at all peripheries is set to be zero and Reynolds boundary condition is used for the cavitation field.

sec.title: Thermal-elastic deformation equation
Solution procedure
sec.p: In this article, the TEHD model which employed finite difference method to solve generalized Reynolds equation, 3D energy equation and heat conduction equation, and obtained the thermal and elastic deformations in the pad and runner with the finite element software ANSYS11.0, was adopted. In the energy equation the convective term is discretized using the upwind differencing scheme to deal with a reverse flow. Central differencing scheme was employed to discretize other terms in energy equation, Reynolds equation and heat conduction equation. Three-dimensional 8-node solid elements named SOLID70 and SOLID45 were used for thermal analysis and structural analysis respectively in the FEM model.

In the oil film domain, 23 × 23 × 5 (r × θ × z) grid points were applied. An identical mesh on the sliding face was used in the FEM model in order to facilitate the data transfer between the THD model and the FEM model. In the FEM model, the pressure boundary is imposed by the APDL command ‘SFE’ in order to obtain the same pressure distribution on the pad surface as in the THD model. The calculated thermal and elastic deformations were used to modified oil film profile, and then obtain new pressure and temperature distributions which were in next step transferred to FEM model again. The data transfer between the THD model and ANSYS11.0 was carried out automatically by an Interface Program. What has to be pointed out is that all the equations concerning the THD model were transformed into dimensionless form in order to improve calculating precision. However, with the restriction of manuscript length, the dimensionless rule which can be found in many other literatures or books was omitted in this article.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
A comparison of the experimental results and numerical predictions in Table 3 shows quite good agreement except for the maximum temperature, which can be attributed to that the maximum temperature appears in the oil while the maximum temperature measured appears in the plane 16 mm below the pad surface. Figures 8 to 10 show the experimental and theoretical temperature contours at three different planes of the pad as presented in Figure 3. It is obvious that the theoretical results and the experimental data show fairly good agreement through the entire field in the pad. However, the experimental peak temperature seems closer to the leading edge and outer radius in Figure 9. Moreover, the experimental temperature gradient is higher in the circumferential direction than that in the radial direction as shown in Figure 8, while the opposite tendency has been found in Figure 10. It is believed to be due to different convection coefficients between different pad surfaces and surrounding oil, or even at different position of the same surface. Therefore, it should be noted that the empirical values of the convection coefficient play an important role in obtaining accurate theoretical temperature distribution. In addition, the contours of experimental and theoretical temperature at the radial section of the runner are shown in Figure 11. Figure 8.

Experimental (left) and theoretical (right) temperature contours at the radial section of the runner.

Figure 12 shows the experimental and theoretical film thickness contours. Although the values of minimum film thickness are quite similar, from an overall point of view, the contours of experimental and theoretical film thickness show poor agreement. This may be attributed to surface roughness or abrasion on the pad. Also, the interpolation algorithm may leads to the difference. Figure 12.
Experimental (left) and theoretical (right) film thickness contours.

The experimental and theoretical oil pressure contours are presented in Figure 13. Cavitated area can be seen at all peripheries of the pad in both of experimental and theoretical results, which proves that the Reynolds boundary condition is applicable. Regardless of the overall distribution trend of oil pressure is followed, there are significant differences in the high pressure region. The theoretical peak pressure is shifted slightly toward the leading edge, and the experimental pressure gradient in the radial direction is a little higher than that in the circumferential direction in the high pressure region. The major reason for such behavior is the existence of the hydrostatic jacking system that is ignored in theoretical calculation. Figure 13.
Experimental (left) and theoretical (right) oil pressure contours.

Figure 14 shows the thermal-elastic deformations in the pad, likewise the thermal-elastic deformations in the runner and thrust block are shown in Figure 15. It has been well known that the temperature gradient through pad thickness and the hydrodynamic pressure would result in convex and concave deformations in the pad respectively. The pad tends to form a convex shape as a result of combined effects of thermal and elastic deformations in this case. The runner tilts up at the outer radius under the load of hydrodynamic pressure and generate a convexity under the load of temperature. The radial tilting of the runner keeps nearly consistent with that of pad, which make both parts remain almost parallel. It is obvious that the deformations on the pad and runner surface are of the same order of magnitude with oil film thickness, which confirms that neither of them is negligible. Figure 14.
Thermal-elastic deformations in the pad. Figure 15.
Thermal-elastic deformations in the runner and thrust block.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The objective of the present research is to verify a TEHD model for bidirectional thrust bearings used in pump-turbines against a detailed experimental investigation. The improved TEHD model couples a 3D THD procedure with ANSYS 11.0 solving the thermal-elastic deformations. A detailed comparison of theoretical results with measurements has been carried out and a fairly good agreement is obtained. Though there are some discrepancies between the theoretical and experimental results, especially the oil film thickness showing poor agreement, the improved TEHD model is accuracy enough for engineering applications.
